text: What is the difference between a normal map and a height map?

options.text: A normal map specifies the direction that a surface is facing at a given point, and a height map specifies how high from the mesh surface to raise the rendered surface.
A normal map contains the data of the basic mesh before rendering, and the height map specifies how high from the normal surface to raise the rendered surface.
A normal map specifies the normal color to render the mesh, and the height map specifies how high the reflectivity of the surface will be rendered.
A normal map specifies the normal properties of the surface, and the height map specifies how those properties change depending on the distance of the surface from the viewer.

feedbackCorrect: Normals are values in the mesh data that define the direction each vertex is facing. A normal map sets these values over an entire surface. Height maps indicate the relative height of each pixel from the mesh.
feedbackIncorrect: Shaders and materials work together to define all the characteristics of a mesh surface during the rendering process. A material is an asset that works with a shader to define how meshes will be rendered.
